case_vignette: A 3-WEEK-OLD NEWBORN IS BROUGHT TO THE PHYSICIAN BY HIS PARENTS BECAUSE OF POOR FEEDING, IRRITABILITY, AND FREQUENT VOMITING OVER THE PAST WEEK. THE VOMITUS IS GREENISH IN COLOR AND SMELLS STRANGE. HIS PARENTS HAVE TRIED TO FEED HIM EVERY 4 HOURS, BUT THE PATIENT OFTEN SPITS UP OR REFUSES TO EAT. THE PATIENT WAS BORN AT TERM AND HAD HIS FIRST BOWEL MOVEMENT AT 50 HOURS OF LIFE. HE HAS SINCE HAD ONE BOWEL MOVEMENT DAILY. HE IS AT THE 50TH PERCENTILE FOR LENGTH, 10TH PERCENTILE FOR WEIGHT, AND 40TH PERCENTILE FOR HEAD CIRCUMFERENCE. HE DOES NOT APPEAR TO BE IN ACUTE DISTRESS. HIS TEMPERATURE IS 36.9°C (98.4°F), PULSE IS 140/MIN, RESPIRATIONS ARE 40/MIN, AND BLOOD PRESSURE IS 90/60 MM HG. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION SHOWS THAT THE PATIENT HAS SMALL, LOW-SET EARS, A BROAD AND FLAT NASAL BRIDGE, AND A LARGE SPACE BETWEEN THE FIRST AND SECOND TOES BILATERALLY. THE ABDOMEN IS DISTENDED. WHEN THE FINGER IS REMOVED FOLLOWING A RECTAL EXAM, THERE IS AN EXPLOSIVE RELEASE OF STOOL FROM THE PATIENT'S RECTUM. AN X-RAY OF THE ABDOMEN SHOWS A SECTION OF DILATED COLON FOLLOWED BY A SEGMENT OF COLON WITHOUT STOOL OR AIR.
question: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS MOST LIKELY TO CONFIRM THE DIAGNOSIS?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting that is greenish in color and smells strange.
How old is the patient?
The patient is a 3-week-old newborn.
Has the baby had any previous medical issues or surgeries?
No, the baby has not had any previous medical issues or surgeries.
Does the baby have any swelling or a bulge in the abdomen?
The abdomen is distended, but there is no specific mention of a bulge.
Has there been any change in bowel movements, like not passing stools or passing unusual stools?
The baby had his first bowel movement at 50 hours of life, usually has one bowel movement daily, and experienced an explosive release of stool during a rectal exam.
Final Diagnosis: Hirschsprung's disease.

The patient has not had any prior medical issues or surgeries. During the examination, it is noted that the abdomen is distended, though no specific bulge was mentioned. The baby had its first bowel movement after 50 hours of life, generally has one bowel movement per day, and experienced an explosive release of stool during a rectal exam.

No, the child does not have any previous medical history or current medications.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting that is greenish and smells strange.
How old is the patient?
The patient is a 3-week-old newborn.
Has the newborn experienced any abdominal distension or changes in bowel movements?
Yes, the newborn's abdomen is distended and he had his first bowel movement at 50 hours of life, with one bowel movement daily since then.
Has the newborn had any recent imaging studies, like an X-ray or ultrasound? If so, what were the results?
Yes, an X-ray of the abdomen was performed and it showed a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air.
Final Diagnosis: Hirschsprung's disease
